statement.text: Brachial artery injury is the most common upper extremity arterial trauma, frequently associated with supracondylar humerus fractures in children and penetrating injuries in adults, requiring prompt recognition through pulse examination and Doppler assessment to prevent limb-threatening ischemia.

explanation.intuition: The brachial artery runs right next to the humerus in the arm. When children break their elbow (supracondylar fracture), the broken bone can stretch, kink, or tear this artery. In adults, stab wounds and gunshot injuries are more common causes. Without blood flow, the hand and forearm muscles can die within hours.
explanation.key_insight: The 'pink pulseless hand' in pediatric supracondylar fractures is a management controversy - observation versus exploration. The key distinction is whether ischemia is from arterial spasm/kinking (may improve with fracture reduction) or from intimal injury/thrombosis (requires repair). Serial examinations and Doppler assessment guide management.
explanation.technical_details: The brachial artery is the continuation of the axillary artery at the lower border of teres major, running medially in the arm then crossing anteriorly at the elbow. It bifurcates into radial and ulnar arteries at the antecubital fossa. Injury mechanisms: (1) Supracondylar fracture in children - arterial kinking, spasm, or intimal injury from displaced fragment; (2) Penetrating trauma - stab/GSW in adults; (3) Iatrogenic - cardiac catheterization, ECMO. Collateral circulation via profunda brachii is usually insufficient for acute occlusion. Management: assess hand perfusion (capillary refill, Doppler signals, pulse oximetry waveform), reduce fracture first if displaced, serial examinations, surgical exploration for persistent ischemia. Repair options: primary anastomosis if <2cm gap, vein interposition graft, or temporary shunt if damage control needed.

pediatric.supracondylar_fracture: Most common cause in children, extension-type injuries
pediatric.mechanism: Anterior spike of proximal fragment injures artery
pediatric.incidence: 10-20% of supracondylar fractures have vascular compromise

adult.iatrogenic: Cardiac catheterization via brachial approach, ECMO

pink_pulseless_hand.definition: Adequate capillary refill and color but absent pulses

management.step_3: Exploration if no improvement in 30-60 minutes or declining perfusion

pink_pulseless_hand.controversy: Some advocate immediate exploration; others observe post-reduction

treatment.non_operative: Observation for pink pulseless hand with improving signs post-reduction

operative.approach: Anteromedial arm incision, may extend across antecubital fossa

treatment.fasciotomy: Consider if prolonged ischemia or significant swelling

definition.@value: Traumatic injury to the brachial artery from fracture, penetrating trauma, or iatrogenic causes, representing the most common upper extremity arterial injury.

learning_objectives: Recognize brachial artery injury patterns in pediatric and adult populations
Assess upper extremity perfusion after trauma
Manage the pink pulseless hand in supracondylar fractures
clinical_pearls: Brachial artery = most common upper extremity arterial injury
Pink pulseless hand: reduce fracture FIRST, then serial exams
Absent Doppler signals = exploration, not observation
Collaterals via profunda brachii are usually INSUFFICIENT for acute occlusion
10-20% of supracondylar fractures have vascular compromise
Consider fasciotomy if prolonged ischemia (>4-6 hours)
